Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Green Net: Energy Management for Network Infrastructure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The Internet as an indispensable communication system in our society has its share in energy consumption. The underlying network infrastructure, however, lacks effective energy management solutions. Not only does the energy consumption cost financially and environmentally, it also has becoming a limiting factor in system performance. Today's networks are aggressively over-provisioned in design and load-balanced in operation for maximum performance resulting in routers and links consuming close to peak energy even when highly underutilized. This project exploits routing path redundancy and low link utilization to design smart routing schemes that allow links to sleep when the network traffic load is low, and wake them up to serve the traffic when the load is high, thus reducing energy consumption while preserving network performance. To achieve this, novel algorithms and protocols for power-aware network routing, traffic engineering, and topology in Internet Service Providers will be designed and evaluated. An energy-efficient network infrastructure will lead to a greener Internet and enable ISPs to reduce energy consumptions while still providing QoS at desired levels. In addition, ISPs will be able to deploy network infrastructure in energy-constrained environments, such as post-disaster recovery and under-developed areas. The tools and techniques developed in this project will provide the research community with a platform and direction for research in network energy management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Internet as an indispensable communication system in our society has its share in energy consumption. Not only does the energy consumption cost financially and environmentally, it also has becoming a limiting factor in system performance. Due to exponential growth in data traffic and Moore’s law in hardware development, router system requirements are outpacing silicon and cooling technologies, putting a lot of stress on power delivery to and heat removal from router components as well as the hosting facility. 

Today’s networks are aggressively over-provisioned in design and load-balanced in operation for maximum performance without any consideration for energy efficiency. Routers and links consume close to peak energy but are highly underutilized most of the time. This leads to poor energy efficiency as well as great power saving opportunity. With high path redundancy and low link utilization, we can design smart routing schemes that allow many links to sleep when the network traffic load is low, and wake them up to serve the traffic when the load is high. This network approach of energy management can improve energy efficiency in network infrastructures, and together with better energy management at end hosts, leading to a greener future Internet. 

The major goals of the GreenNet project are to develop network protocols and traffic engineering mechanisms to improve the overall energy efficiency of computer network infrastructures, and develop evaluation framework to quantify the gains and costs of such new schemes. Over the course of this project, we have the following major accomplishments:

 

  • We designed, implemented, and evaluated GreenTE, one of the first power-aware traffic engineering schemes. It reduces power consumption by merging traffic onto a fewer number of paths so that links on other paths do not need to carry any traffic and can be put into sleep mode for a certain period of time. GreenTE takes into consideration the network topology, traffic demands, and the performance requirements of packet delivery. Using real and synthetic network topologies and traffic, simulations show that GreenTE is able to reduce power consumption significantly while meeting requirements on link utilization and network delay. This work was awarded the Applied Networking Research Award by Internet Society (ISOC) and the Internet Research Task Force (IRTF) in 2011.

 

  • We designed, implemented, and evaluated PALS, a power-aware link-state routing protocol that computes energy-efficient paths in a distributed fashion without a central server to carry out the optimization like in GreenTE. 

 

  • In addition to intra-domain traffic engineering, we analyzed the potential benefits and overheads of conducting power-aware inter-domain traffic engineering. The conclusion, however, is that the gain of inter-domain traffic engineering is not significant enough to warrant the changes in related protocols and operation practice.

 

  • By measuring and analyzing the power consumption of various components in a commercial router, we obtained a good understanding of where energy was spent in a router and identified a number of places where improvement will bring significant energy savings. One of the issues is that even a line-card is put into sleep, currently it will take minutes to wake up, which makes it impractical to put a line-card into sleep. We analyzed the boot process of a line-card and proposed a solution that can reduce the line-card’s boot time to milliseconds. This is a key technique to enable effective energy management in routers.

 

  •  We measured the power consumption of several home routers and the transition time required to switch power states or enable/disable components. After analyzing weeks of traffic traces from several household, we proposed a number of techniques to improve energy efficiency of home routers. The techniques were evaluated in simulations using real traces, and also implemented in DD-WRT based home routers to demonstrate their feasibility.

 

  • During this course of this project, we have developed various evaluation tools and prototype systems. They include simulations for GreenTE and PALS, lab testbed for profiling the performance and energy consumption of a small network, SDN implementation of GreenTE, and energy consumption data of a real router.

 

Broader Impacts: 

This project proposes and develops the concept of Power-Aware Networking (PANET), which advocates that energy efficiency should be considered in network protocol design and operations. We collaborated with industrial labs and participated in related activities in the IETF/IRTF community to raise the awareness of the problems and discuss practical solutions. Our measurement, analysis, and solution proposals  contribute to making the Internet a greener and more sustainable infrastructure.

 

As part of this project, we have developed a new course, Green Computing, offered to both graduate students and senior undergraduates. We also introduced related course materials into courses on operating systems and computer networks. A number of graduate and undergraduate students participated the project research and received rigorous training in a broad set of topics, including system building, network protocol design and evaluation, and green computing.
